channel.title: math.GM updates on arXiv.org
channel.description: math.GM updates on the arXiv.org e-print archive.

item.title: A characterization and an explicit description of all primitive polynomials of degree two over finite fields
item.description: arXiv:2409.17147v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: For polynomials of degree two over finite fields, we present an improvement of Fitzgerald's characterization (Finite Fields Appl. 9(1):117-121, 2003). We then use this new characterization to obtain an explicit, complete, and simple description of all primitive polynomials of degree two over finite fields.
item.dc:creator: Gerardo Vega

item.title: A short note on a definite integral of a general form
item.description: arXiv:2409.17149v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: In this note we derive some interesting definite integrals involving Malmsten logarithm forms, reciprocal logarithm forms and K\"{o}lbig type integrals in terms of special functions.
item.dc:creator: Robert Reynolds

item.title: Penrose's eight-conic theorem via Penrose's eight-quadric theorem
item.description: arXiv:2409.17150v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: This article proves the following theorem, first enunciated by Roger Penrose about 70 years ago: In $\mathbb{RP}^2$, if regular conics are assigned to seven of the vertices of a combinatorial cube such that conics connected by an edge are in double contact, and the chords of contact associated to a cube face have a common point, then there exists a unique eighth conic which completes the cube and satisfies the same conditions. The proof is based on the following analogue theorem: In $\mathbb{RP}^3$, if regular quadrics are assigned to seven of the vertices of a combinatorial cube such that quadrics connected by an edge are in ring contact, and the ring planes associated to a cube face have a common axis, then there exists a unique eighth quadric which completes the cube and satisfies the same conditions.
item.dc:creator: Russell Arnold, Albert Chern, Charles Gunn, Thomas Neukirchner, Roger Penrose
